title-group.article-title: Body sizes of species determining the success of biological control in a three-level food chain

abstract.p: Biological control in plant–insect systems represents a fundamental challenge in theoretical ecology, particularly within agricultural systems. This challenge is amplified by climate change, which, through increasing temperatures, has induced variations in insect body size, altering their ecological interactions and, consequently, their abundance. Although allometric relationships provide a static description of the relationship between body size, metabolism, and population density, dynamic models are needed to adequately simulate agroecological systems. In this context, incorporating body size as a dynamic parameter in trophic models offers an analytic approach to linking climate-induced morphological changes with the effectiveness of biological control and the indirect effects on plants. The main objective of this study is to develop a mathematical model based on a three-level food chain (plant–pest-biological control), where body size is incorporated as a key parameter in the dynamics of the plant–pest biological control system. Specifically, the goals are to: 1) Identify the relationships between the body sizes of species that limit population densities and prevent coexistence. 2) Determine the body size relationships that promote the success of biological control. 3) Model the trophic cascade effect as a function of body size and analyze its indirect impact on plants. Through theoretical analysis, indicators based on body sizes are proposed to evaluate the effectiveness of biological control strategies. The results suggest that allometric relationships between body sizes can modify the qualitative behavior of the system, offering a potential tool for evaluating biological control strategies based on these indicators. This study offers a tool for evaluating biological control strategies based on key indicators, complementing experimental designs and advancing integrated pest management through an interdisciplinary framework in which biomathematical models serve as a foundation for digital agriculture.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Rising temperatures are driving changes in body size across diverse species, suggesting that this could represent a third universal response to global warming1. Since body size influences an organism’s ability to dissipate or retain heat, increasing temperatures can affect both thermoregulation and energy efficiency. In this context, a reduction in body size could constitute an adaptive response driven by global warming. Several studies have suggested that the adaptive value of body size may be linked to its influence on fecundity or as a response to altered developmental patterns resulting from increased mortality under warmer conditions2–5. Additionally, body size can act as a limiting factor for oxygen availability, exerting selective pressure that favors a reduction in body size as temperatures rise6,7. Although these changes may be subtle, their repercussions could extend to larger scales, affecting agricultural production and crop sustainability. Eventually, this could impact food availability and compromise food security8. Insects are particularly affected, as their thermal limits are altered, impacting their metabolism and, consequently, their body size, making shifts in abundances likely5,9,10. However, it remains unclear how these body size changes will influence ecosystem dynamics or pest control strategies4.

In agricultural systems, it is essential to have reliable indicators derived from experimental and/or theoretical designs that facilitate the development of effective strategies for pest control through the introduction of natural biological control agents32,33. This approach aims to eradicate pests while minimizing the use of chemical products, thus promoting sustainable resource management. From a practical perspective, biological control strategies often involve experimental processes that can be costly and time-consuming; however, these can be complemented and optimized through theoretical research based on the analysis of mathematical models that describe the dynamics between plants, pests, and biological control agents34,35. A key indicator of pest control success is the body size of the species. Although the relationship between body size, plant growth rate, carrying capacity, predation rates (functional responses), and abundance has been extensively studied using systems of ordinary differential equations22–25,36,37, there remains limited research on mathematical relationships with ecological interpretation between body sizes for effective biological control and cascade effect modeling, which are crucial for the development of management strategies38. Furthermore, while body size relationships between two species (plant–herbivore; prey–predator)14 have been explored, the emergence of ecological patterns linking the body sizes of three species simultaneously remains an underexplored area.

This analytical approach complements the broader understanding gained through simulation modelling41 and provides a structured and transparent framework for incorporating body size into ecological models. Framed within ecological theory, it provides a scientific basis for predicting potential behaviours of pest control systems and for designing strategies in agroecological contexts affected by body size modifications induced by rising temperatures. By connecting morphological traits with ecosystem-level outcomes, this modelling framework supports multidisciplinary collaboration with entomologists and other specialists. It can also help the design of experiments aimed at determining optimal body size configurations for effective biological control, and promote clear documentation, validation, and communication of modelling assumptions and results, as recommended in practical ecological modelling approaches42. In this way, mathematical modelling emerges as an accessible and conceptually robust tool with the potential to support applied research, foster a deeper understanding of natural systems, and contribute to more informed decision-making in the context of digital agriculture.

sec.title: The model
Functional responses
sec.p: For the generation of the images, Python was used along with the following libraries: numpy (for array manipulation and numerical calculations) and matplotlib.pyplot (for creating plots), mpl.toolkits.mplot3d (for 3D plotting), and matplotlib.ticker.MaxNLocator (for customizing the tick locations on the axes). For solving the differential equations, the libraries numpy and matplotlib.pyplot were used for data handling and visualization, in addition to scipy.integrate.solve.ivp to numerically solving initial value differential equations.

sec.title: Results
Body size relationships that govern the existence and local stability of equilibrium densities
The effect of trophic cascade modeled by body sizes
Discussion
sec.p: Insect pest outbreaks affecting agricultural production represent a critical threat to food security, and management strategies can become increasingly complex due to adaptive responses, particularly changes in body size driven by rising temperatures7,53–55. These temperature-induced shifts can alter insect body size, potentially impacting their interactions with natural resources. Developing management strategies based on easily measurable indicators is essential to address this challenge. This study proposes body size-dependent indicators within a three-level food chain (plant–pest–biological control). These indicators assess abundance, persistence, potential extinctions within biological control, and trophic cascade effects, providing a framework to evaluate and optimize pest management in dynamic ecological contexts. The model from which these indicators are derived is based on a system of differential equations parameterized according to body size, in accordance with the Metabolic Theory of Ecology11,23–25. Recent research has studied the dynamic structure of the model considering a Holling Type I functional response, in order to connect coexistence theory25. Additionally, this type of model has been analyzed in detail by Kuznetsov et al.48, who provided an in-depth view of the possible bifurcations described in Eqs. (11) and (12). In our proposal, we present an applied approach that offers a better understanding of how changes in body size impact ecological mechanisms and the structure of the tritrophic dynamic system represented56. Equations (9) and (10) (which describe population densities without biological control), along with Eqs. (13)–(16) (representing the coexistence of the three species), illustrate the dependence of coexistence on body size, providing a valuable perspective for studying strong and weak trophic interactions in ecological communities57,58.

Environmental changes influence body size, which in turn affects predator behavior, altering trophic interactions and the physiology of herbivores54, yet there are no biological indicators that account for these factors. This study presents a theoretical proposal for an indicator based on Eq. (5) to establish a limit on species abundance. Experimentally, it could support the design of studies similar to those conducted in the United States, such as the case of the spruce budworm (Choristoneura fumiferana), which has migrated northward with reduced populations at lower latitudes, and the hemlock woolly adelgid (Adelges tsugae), which has similarly expanded its distribution northward while declining in the south due to heat intolerance in young nymphs56. In conjunction with this, the relationships between body sizes in Eqs. (6), (7), and (8) could be used to indicate potential extinction conditions, anticipate critical experimental situations, and contribute to integrated pest management from a multidisciplinary perspective59.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1038/s41598-025-16157-4.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: W.C-L. expresses gratitude to the multidisciplinary scientific environment where this research began at the Centre for Research and Transfer in Irrigation and Agroclimatology (CITRA) at the University of Talca, as well as to the support provided by the Department of Mathematical and Physical Sciences at the Catholic University of Temuco. Additionally, the work of Marlon M. López-Flores was partially funded by the Project EVAAT_GCN (FINEP Convênio 01.24.0661.00 ref. 3311/24).

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: W.C-L. contributed to the initial drafting of the manuscript and the overall study planning. Data visualisation and the generation of mathematical results were jointly developed by W.C-L. and M.M.L-F., who ensured precision and clarity in the analyses. S.O-F. and G.A.D. led the interdisciplinary discussion of agronomic concepts, bringing their expertise to contextualise and deepen the findings from an applied perspective in agricultural sciences. All co-authors actively participated in the critical review of the final version and approved the manuscript before its formal submission.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: All data and parameter values used in this study were obtained from previously published scientific research, which is appropriately cited throughout the manuscript.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.
